thread.title: How the 'Brexit effect' on sterling means Florian Lejeune will cost £1.2m more than a year ago

author: Chris Waugh
title: How the 'Brexit effect' on sterling means Florian Lejeune will cost £1.2m more than a year ago
text:
Sport How the 'Brexit effect' on sterling means Florian Lejeune will cost £1.2m more than a year ago Newcastle United boss Rafa Benitez is keen to get transfer business concluded - but inflationary pressures have made the market expensive Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Newcastle United FC   Thank you for subscribing! The current transfer market is ludicrous. There is no other way to describe the marketplace in which Newcastle United are attempting to work within. 
You need only look at the fees being spent: £30million on Jordan Pickford , £20m on Nathan Ake, £17m on Harry Maguire. 
There have been are a whole host of inflationary pressures on the market over the past two years. These range from the astronomical fees being paid by Chinese clubs to lure top European players to East Asia, as well as the latest top-flight TV deal. 
Clubs such as AFC Bournemouth, Watford and Burnley are willing to invest significantly in their squads this summer due to the more-than-£100m payouts they are receiving annually from the Premier League. 
But there is another significant factor which has driven the cost of European imports up further: the Brexit effect. Read More 
On Wednesday, June 22 - the day immediately before the European Union referendum took place - £1 was worth €1.30. 
Fast-forward little more than 12 months, and £1 is worth just €1.13. 
In real terms, that means that the pound in your pocket is worth 14 per cent less on the Continent than it was little more than a year ago. 
That may not appear to be a huge change, but it certainly is when you are attempting to do multi-million-pound transactions with European clubs. 
Paul Pogba’s world-record €100m transfer from Juventus to Manchester United, for example, would have cost the Red Devils £76m before the Brexit vote. Man United actually forked out £89m; as a result of sterling’s value collapsing, the Red Devils were forced to pay an additional £13m to bring the French midfielder back to Old Trafford. Gareth Bale of Real Madrid shakes hands with Florian Lejeune (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Rafa Benitez’s summer transfer plans have also been affected by this reduction in the real-term value of the pound. 
The Newcastle boss has been using his extensive contacts on the Continent to try and find some reasonably-priced players to import into England. 
However, the Brexit effect on sterling has made recruiting from Europe more expensive. 
Florian Lejeune has a €10m buyout clause in his Eibar contract. Little more than 12 months ago, it would have cost Newcastle £7.6m to activate it. They will need to pay around £8.8m in order to lure the centre-back to Tyneside in the coming weeks. 
Again that £1.2m increase may not seem significant, but multiply that over five transfers costing roughly the same and suddenly that is an additional £6m - or potentially even the cost of another player - which has been spent. Read More
